title: Tribunal and Jury Governance
outcome: The free zone councils, newly empowered by resource control and public support, convene a public tribunal for remaining Council members. Street assemblies demand answers about Halden's death. Under pressure, a Harmonist confesses past abuses, including audit manipulation during early BCI pilot phases. The city holds a public vote to decide the fate of leadership, launching randomly-selected citizen juries as a new model of power. The tribunal and vote signal a break from both old compliance systems and Council rule, fundamentally reshaping Stenograd's politics.

events.description: Free zone councils call for an open tribunal. The process will be public, with citizens supplying evidence and questions for Council members.
A street tribunal commences. Under growing pressure and overwhelming public testimony, a senior Harmonist Council member publicly admits to BCI audit manipulation during early pilot phases.

The tribunal shifts from accusatory hearings to proposals for new leadership. Free zone organizers urge the use of random citizen juries, echoing early BCI randomization protocols but for civic power.
A citywide vote is held: majority backs replacing the Council with randomly-selected citizen juries. The BCI scoring system remains but with power to review and overrule embedded in the juries.
First citizen juries assume oversight. Former Council members step aside. The transition is tense but nonviolent, and Stenograd enters a phase of self-government and systematic review.
